body: @dusenberrymw Do you think this should be merged before the 1.0.0 release? In communication with @feihugis, it seems like setting the 'runtime platform'/'execution type' can be useful, and having it built into the API can avoid the need for code such as `org.apache.sysml.api.DMLScript.rtplatform = org.apache.sysml.api.DMLScript.RUNTIME_PLATFORM.SPARK`.
ping @dusenberrymw
Test this Jenkins
ping @nakul02 could you please review.
@nakul02 could you please review/merge this PR. Will also update this document at the end of Phase2 and Phase3.

Thank you for working on this @j143. GLM-predict.dml LGTM. I will need another day to review GLM.dml. The previous code (which has things such as 22 or 23 levels of nested if/else statements) is quite tricky to review and validate.

@dhutchis modifying `wumm` to recognize if there is a "multiply by constant" outside the `W*(U%*%t(V))`, seems a best option.

Got it! A new `wumm` pattern kicks in after the element-wise multiply rewrite:

> 17/07/13 01:05:46 DEBUG rewrite.HopRewriteRule: Element-wise multiply chain rewrite of 2 e-mults at sub-dag 136 to new sub-dag 144
> 17/07/13 01:05:46 DEBUG rewrite.RewriteAlgebraicSimplificationDynamic: Applied simplifyWeightedUnaryMM2.7 (line 24)

thanks @dhutchis - overall this looks already very good. 

Just one minor knit pick: could you please add a condition of nl.getParent().size()==1 to the new wumm rewrite to ensure we only merge this in if there are not multiple consumers, because the *2 is non-essential for the fused operator and we would redundantly compile a wdivmm in this case as well.

Regarding the modification of wumm, I would have actually recommended to disable the respective tests because even with wdivmm and *2 it would be sparsity-exploiting and these fused operators are going to be superseded by codegen anyway soon. However, since you've already done the work, we'll of course go with the modified rewrite. Thanks.
I rebased and started looking into it a while ago - let me see what I can do over the weekend. What's the release plan for 1.0?

ok thanks again for catching - this specific issue has been fixed. However, while running this scenario also in hybrid_spark mode and different memory budgets, I additionally ran into unrelated OOMs. I'll follow up on this separately.

@nakul02 could you please share your thoughts on this initial approach. 

Also what do you think of the following points below:
a) Createing common utils files that can be shared by `systemml-spark-submit.py` and `systemml-standalone.py`. (Common functions like `get_env`, `default_jars`, `find_script_file` etc...)
b) Change `systemml-standalone.py` to point `jars` instead of `classes`.

I have tested `systemml-spark-submit.py` and it works on my local system with the commands below. 

```
./systemml-spark-submit.py -f genRandData4Kmeans.dml -nvargs nr=10000 nf=1000 nc=50 dc=10.0 dr=1.0 fbf=100.0 cbf=100.0 X=data/X.data C=data/C.data Y=data/Y.data YbyC=data/YbyC.data fmt=csv
./systemml-spark-submit.py -f ~/open-source/matmul.dml
```
Squashed into one commit and rebased onto master.

Has the synchronization enabled in other way, than this PR. I believe there is no `synchronized` in the [file](https://github.com/apache/systemml/blob/master/src/main/java/org/apache/sysml/runtime/util/LocalFileUtils.java#L313).

cc @deroneriksson

@j143 yes, I had to change this to make both creation and cleanup robust enough. We now synchronize in parfor workers because multiple setups and cleanup registrations needs to happen atomically. The cleanup is handled via a shutdown hook of the executor process.

The relevant commit and jira are here
https://github.com/apache/systemml/commit/b78c125934fa7a947a5118f0c08473afa926fa5d
https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/SYSTEMML-1309

Do you really think that's a good idea? Our stats output is meant to provide concise summary statistics, while these statistics here with their extended opcodes seem to be too convoluted for most users. At the same time, they simply do not provide sufficient information for dev performance debugging (e.g., breakdowns of sparse/dense, input/output data sizes, performance per category), which renders them - at least for me - useless. So to avoid yet another configuration property, I would recommend to drop this.

Refer to this link for build results (access rights to CI server needed): 
https://sparktc.ibmcloud.com/jenkins/job/SystemML-PullRequestBuilder/1764/

@niketanpansare - I am all for finer grained statistics. These are useful, specially for someone like trying to debug performance problems in a large complicated DML Script. 

In fact, if you've seen the GPU extra statistics, I would love to have that for all the important ops. 

As of now, what we get are aggregated numbers and it is very hard to glean **where** something is going wrong.  (for instance, if a `ba+*` takes 90% of the time, I cannot tell which particular instance of the call is actually taking the most amount of time).

Also, since this is being introduced as a configuration property, IMO, it is ok to add. 

This is just me. I would ask @dusenberrymw to weigh in, since he has a lot of experience developing and running DML programs.

We can talk about the formatting and such, but overall, this is a feature in the right direction for more detailed performance characteristics collection.

Refer to this link for build results (access rights to CI server needed): 
https://sparktc.ibmcloud.com/jenkins/job/SystemML-PullRequestBuilder/1765/
Being able to optionally turn on fine-grained statistics seems like it has the potential to be useful to begin to narrow down the causes of performance issues.
Test this Jenkins
Can an Admin verify this patch?
Awesome, glad this is fixed.  @feihugis Can you close this PR now?

Yeah we should definitely merge this functionality.  Is everyone okay with the updated names of `DRIVER` instead of `SINGLE_NODE`, and `DRIVER_AND_SPARK` instead of `HYBRID_SPARK`?  To me they are clearer, but it does introduce inconsistencies.  cc @nakul02
Can this be updated now?

BTW the MLContext API naming differences vs the 'internal' global rtplatform in DMLScript are:
DMLScript.RUNTIME_PLATFORM.SINGLE_NODE -> ExecutionType.DRIVER
DMLScript.RUNTIME_PLATFORM.SPARK -> ExecutionType.SPARK
DMLScript.RUNTIME_PLATFORM.HADOOP -> ExecutionType.HADOOP
DMLScript.RUNTIME_PLATFORM.HYBRID_SPARK -> ExecutionType.DRIVER_AND_SPARK
DMLScript.RUNTIME_PLATFORM.HYBRID -> ExecutionType.DRIVER_AND_HADOOP

The reasoning for this:
SINGLE_NODE is confusing since SystemML can run in CP on a single node, Spark can run on a single node, and Hadoop can run on a single node.
HYBRID is CP+Hadoop, whereas HYBRID_SPARK is CP+Spark. The name 'HYBRID' is not descriptive of the Hadoop part of CP+Hadoop.

I am not 100% happy with the term DRIVER but I think it is more descriptive than SINGLE_NODE.

Maybe we all understand something different under "performance profiling" but from my perspective it is not useful to extend the opcode by the line numbers. Assume you have a function foo that is called with different sizes and sparse/dense matrices. The extended opcode, let's say for a particular indexing operation, in foo still mixes up completely different characteristics. What we usually do is to determine the major bottleneck via stats and subsequently instrument the code to get the actual relevant breakdown for dense/sparse, different code paths, and so on.

+1 to the renaming suggestions.
If possible, we could have the `internal` and `external` names be the same. Appropriate changes in the launch scripts & @krishnakalyan3's performance test scripts would be needed too.

Thank you for reviewing @dusenberrymw and @nakul02. I'll merge.

I think standardizing the internal/external names would be great, especially if we could address the lack of clarity regarding the 1) SINGLE_NODE and 2) HYBRID vs HYBRID_SPARK internal representations. I would also be very happy with names such as:
  SINGLE_NODE -> CP
  HYBRID -> HYBRID_HADOOP

For initial profiling or for high-level understanding, I agree with @nakul02 , @deroneriksson and @dusenberrymw on the utility of providing the line numbers especially since this is an optional feature with no overhead.  

For advanced profiling, based on @mboehm7 and @nakul02 feedback, may be we can further extend this to provide additional breakdown without requiring instrumentation of the code, as the instrumented code cannot be reused by others ... let's discuss this approach in a separate PR. What is the reasoning behind these inconsistent and misleading execution modes? Singlenode means CP, hybrid means CP and MR, and hybrid_spark means CP and SPARK - note that CP instructions are not necessarily executed in the driver (e.g., if the parfor optimizer decides for remote execution, then CP instructions are executed in the executor processes and map/reduce tasks respectively).

@mboehm7 Statements such as "hybrid means CP and MR, and hybrid_spark means CP and SPARK" point out the confusing, inconsistent naming in DMLScript.RUNTIME_PLATFORM. Using a name such as "hybrid" instead of "hybrid_hadoop" or "hybrid_mapreduce" obfuscates meaning for our users and just does not make sense to me.

globally renaming hybrid to hybrid_mr as well as hadoop to mr is fine, I just don't think that "DRIVER" is a good choice because it attaches a location, which is not necessarily true with parfor or containerized jmlc deployments.
btw, the name hybrid is not too far fetched, because we switch automatically from hybrid_mr to hybrid_spark when we recognize that we're running in a spark context (at least through spark_submit).
@dusenberrymw great! I will try to implement this in a modular way, with core `fm.dml` file.

so what's the conclusion here: revert or create global consistency?

The original intent of these modes was to specify what kind of runtime instructions can be generated. It was primarily internally. Later with different SystemML deployment modes, the same “flag” was used for the user to be able to specify the deployment mode.

From user’s perspective, there are 2 or 3 modes depending on how you count: no use of a data parallel platform, i.e. single node, or use of data parallel platform, i.e. MR, or Spark. Yes, you can run MR and Spark on single node, but from SystemML perspective it is still using a data parallel platform.

If people don’t like to use “CP”, or “DRIVER”, or “SINGLE_NODE”, may be “LOCAL” is a better choice. I think using “HYBRID …” is very descriptive and important for SystemML.

There should be 3 modes exposed to the user:
(1) LOCAL
(2) HYBRID_MR
(3) HYBRID_SPARK

Internally, we should not get rid of SPARK and MR modes as they are being used for experimentation, debugging, and developing forcing all ops to SPARPK or MR. But they are useless to the user.

As @mboehm7 pointed out, "the high-level summary: the problematic expression is indeed `X %*% t(X)` (in function distance_matrix). Given the 60Kx784 input, this output matrix is 60Kx60K, i.e., 29GB in dense. "

Here, I would like to know whether we are using any *special property* of multiplication with self transpose such as symmetry or we are doing an *ordinary* matrix multiplication.

the only expensive functions here: 
1. `X %*% t(X)` 
2. `W %*% Y` 

if we are using *ordinary* matrix multiplication, we can try for an efficient way of implementing it. This will help resolve this [SYSTEMML-831].

cc @niketanpansare
